Hi there again,

I want to rework the UI color tokens.

I want to keep it as simple as possible, while also trying to remain flexible.

Here is what I come up with my self.

## V1 - Simple as shit tokens

The simplest token system I can think of.

Important would be that every fg token needs enough contrast to every bg token.

One question though about neovim. What highlight group is respsonsible for the *vim.lsp.buf.hover()* window?
The hover window in Neovim uses these main highlight groups:

1. `NormalFloat` - The main background and text color of the floating window
2. `FloatBorder` - The border of the floating window
3. `FloatTitle` - The title of the floating window (if any)

So in our UI tokens, it would use:
- `bg.float` for the background
- `fg.default` for the text
- `fg.subtle` for the border (or sometimes `fg.accent` for emphasis)

You can see this in use in our UI highlights:
```lua
NormalFloat = { fg = ui.fg.default, bg = ui.bg.float },
FloatBorder = { fg = ui.fg.subtle, bg = ui.bg.float },
FloatTitle = { fg = ui.fg.accent, bg = ui.bg.float },
```

You can verify these highlight groups while the hover window is open with:
```vim
:Inspect   " hover your cursor over the element you want to check
" or
:verbose highlight NormalFloat
:verbose highlight FloatBorder
:verbose highlight FloatTitle
```
